content:
ass="word-wrap-span">MARIE STOPES’S marriage to ass="word-wrap-span">Reginald Ruggles ass="word-wrap-span">Gates was not a long or a happy one. In 1912, a year after their wedding, ass="word-wrap-span">She sought legal advice; a year after that, ass="word-wrap-span">She filed for divorce, claiming that the union had never been consummated. As ass="word-wrap-span">She instigated divorce proceedings, Stopes decided to reflect on what ass="word-wrap-span">She had learned from the sorry affair. “ass="word-wrap-span">Were I to touch upon all the possible sources of marital disappointment and unhappiness,” ass="word-wrap-span">She quipped, “this book would expand into a dozen bulky volumes.” ass="word-wrap-span">She hoped instead to offer some observations on what makes a partnership happy and successful, and to save other young couples “years of heartache”.

In “Married ass="word-wrap-span">Love; or, ass="word-wrap-span">Love in ass="word-wrap-span">Marriage”, ass="word-wrap-span">She preached ass="word-wrap-span">The importance of mutual respect and freedom, and allowing women to pursue ass="word-wrap-span">Their intellectual interests. ass="word-wrap-span">She reminded men ass="word-wrap-span">That ass="word-wrap-span">They must practise ass="word-wrap-span">The “ass="word-wrap-span">Art of ass="word-wrap-span">Love” throughout ass="word-wrap-span">Marriage, not merely in its heady early days. ass="word-wrap-span">But what made “Married ass="word-wrap-span">Love” a sensation after its publication in 1918—it sold 2,000 copies in ass="word-wrap-span">The first two weeks—was its forthright approach to sex. ass="word-wrap-span">Though ass="word-wrap-span">She claimed still to be a virgin herself, Stopes described ass="word-wrap-span">The act in scientific terms (and indeed recommended positions in which to “make it quite satisfactory”). ass="word-wrap-span">She contemplated ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">appropriate frequency of sexual union and reflected on ass="word-wrap-span">The importance of birth control. “ass="word-wrap-span">That girls can reach a ass="word-wrap-span">Marriageable age without some knowledge of ass="word-wrap-span">The realities of sex would seem incredible: ass="word-wrap-span">But it is a fact,” Stopes wrote. “ass="word-wrap-span">There are known not a few cases in which ass="word-wrap-span">The horror of ass="word-wrap-span">The first night of ass="word-wrap-span">Marriage...has driven ass="word-wrap-span">The bride to suicide or insanity.”

ass="word-wrap-span">She invited her readers to write to her and share their own experiences—and write they did. In “ass="word-wrap-span">Wise ass="word-wrap-span">Parenthood”, a book publiass="word-wrap-span">Shed later in 1918 which dealt with the subject of contraception in more detail, Stopes said that so ass="word-wrap-span">Many people had sent letters “that it became impossible to answer each ass="word-wrap-span">One personally”. ass="word-wrap-span">Thousands wrote to her with hopes, fears, queries and confessions. ass="word-wrap-span">One correspondent admits that they “do not know how to begin”, given the sensitive nature of the complaint. ass="word-wrap-span">Many who sought out Stopes were desperate: “ass="word-wrap-span">Please believe, ass="word-wrap-span">Please believe that I need your help” and “I have been with two doctors but they can’t say what is wrong or what to do.”

“ass="word-wrap-span">Dear ass="word-wrap-span">Marie Stopes”, a new chamber opera, opens with spoken recordings of snippets of these letters. A soprano, contralto and countertenor—ie, two female singers and one male—give voice to others. A woman asks for Stopes’s advice: she has had 14 children, and her doctor has said that if she has another her weak heart will give out. A man laments a problem with premature ejaculation. A woman is scared by “the thought of marital relations” and has no mother or sister to ask for guidance; another has contracted venereal disease and is desperate to be cured. Of course, not all those who wrote to Stopes were pleased that she had discussed such private matters publicly. Referring to Stopes’s Scottish ass="word-wrap-span">ancestry, one angry correspondent informed her that she should “go back to [her] own country” for “decent ass="word-wrap-span">English people are disgusted by your filthy suggestions”.

Jennifer Thorp, ass="word-wrap-span">The librettist, scoured ass="word-wrap-span">These letters, which are kept in ass="word-wrap-span">The archive at ass="word-wrap-span">The Wellcome ass="word-wrap-span">Collection in London. “ass="word-wrap-span">The weight of ass="word-wrap-span">The pleas and vitriol that came at Stopes for decades almost has to be seen to be believed,” ass="word-wrap-span">She says. “ass="word-wrap-span">She was a public beacon of aid in an age where birth control was highly illegal, sexual education was obscure and women in particular were often kept in ass="word-wrap-span">The dark.” Ms Thorp argues that ass="word-wrap-span">The missives are well-suited to opera not only because of ass="word-wrap-span">Their emotional intensity but also because ass="word-wrap-span">They had a kind of rhythm and pattern. ass="word-wrap-span">They are set to music which is haunting but simple, driven by a cello and a viola da gamba. Something “atonal and ass="word-wrap-span">angular would have distracted from ass="word-wrap-span">The intimacy of ass="word-wrap-span">The text,” ass="word-wrap-span">Alex Mills, ass="word-wrap-span">The composer, says.

Stopes features in ass="word-wrap-span">The opera—intriguingly, her parts are sung by ass="word-wrap-span">The male countertenor so that her voice is more easily distinguishable from those of ass="word-wrap-span">The letter-writers—but she is not its main subject. To have told ass="word-wrap-span">The story of her life would have meant delving into ass="word-wrap-span">The more controversial aspects of her legacy, particularly her views on eugenics, which were bound up with her attitude towards birth control (she thought that it was necessary to “deal with ass="word-wrap-span">The inferior, ass="word-wrap-span">The depraved and feeble-minded” so that “ass="word-wrap-span">The good in our race is not to be swamped and destroyed”). “ass="word-wrap-span">Dear ass="word-wrap-span">Marie Stopes” ass="word-wrap-span">acknowledges those views, but it prefers to focus on ass="word-wrap-span">The people she helped through her writings and, later, through her birth-control clinic, which was ass="word-wrap-span">The first of its kind in ass="word-wrap-span">Britain. “ass="word-wrap-span">The opera brings home ass="word-wrap-span">The immense human cost of sexual repression and illegal contraception, and how much damage it wrought on millions of private lives,” Ms Thorp says.

ass="word-wrap-span">After its performances in London, Mr Mills hopes to take ass="word-wrap-span">The opera to ass="word-wrap-span">America, where, today, ass="word-wrap-span">The debate around reproductive rights is particularly febrile. ass="word-wrap-span">But he stresses that its message, about ass="word-wrap-span">The importance of education and access to family-planning services, applies to ass="word-wrap-span">The developing world, too. It is ass="word-wrap-span">There that an international charity set up in ass="word-wrap-span">Marie Stopes’s name focuses its resources. “ass="word-wrap-span">There are more than 200m [women] around ass="word-wrap-span">The world who don’t want to get pregnant ass="word-wrap-span">But can’t get modern contraception,” ass="word-wrap-span">The organisation’s website says. It provides more than 25m people with ass="word-wrap-span">The help ass="word-wrap-span">They need.
